chapter.title: What is a bond?
chapter.paragraph: A bond is a debt investment in which an investor loans money to an entity which borrows the funds for a defined period of time at a variable or fixed interest rate. Bonds are used by companies, municipalities, states and sovereign governments to raise money and finance a variety of projects and activities. Owners of bonds are debtholders, or creditors, of the issuer.

The recent data leak of Panama Papers is already consider the biggest of the history, and in fact is truly so! It contains the internal documents of Mossak Fonseca, a Panamanian law firm that helps people to set up companies in tax havens, and revealed that some of the world’s richest people were evading taxes and hiding ill-gotten money through offshore accounts. Nothing new under the sun may you say, but let’s go deeper into matters.

chapter.title: A matter of fact
chapter.paragraph: Of the companies that appear in Mossack Fonseca’s files, one out of every two were incorporated in the British Virgin Islands. The second favorite jurisdiction was Panama, where the firm is headquartered.
Mossak Fonseca worked with more than 14,000 banks, law firms, company incorporators and other middlemen to set up companies, foundations and trusts for customer.

chapter.paragraph: The persistence of financial flows routed through offshore financial mechanisms highlights the pressing need to create greater coherence among tax and investment policies at the global level.

The leaks include 11.5 million documents for a total of 2.6 terabytes of material. It covers a period spanning from the 1970s to the spring of 2016.

chapter.paragraph: According to The Hidden Wealth of Nations, a recent book by University of California, Berkeley economist Gabriel Zucman, the answer is that tax evasion costs governments approximately $200 billion per year. Zucman also estimates that tax avoidance by U.S. corporations—which, unlike tax evasion, is generally carried out in the open and is technically legal—costs governments an additional $130 billion per year.

section.title: Mass protests in Iceland call for PM to quit

chapter.paragraph: Iceland’s embattled prime minister, Sigmundur Davíð Gunnlaugsson, has become the first major casualty of the Panama Papers, stepping aside from his office amid mounting public outrage that his family had sheltered money offshore.
The prime minister of Iceland secretly owned the debt of failed Icelandic banks while he was involved in political negotiations over their fate.

At the end of 2014, the 50 largest US companies held a combined total of nearly $1.4 trillion dollars offshore, which is more than the entire gross-domestic product of Mexico, shows a report released today by Oxfam.

Those offshore holdings helped lower the combined effective global-tax rate for those companies from 35%, the rate US corporations are required to pay on their profits, to 27%, according to the report.
